title: PULSE;Immigration
body:
Immigration in this region jumped in the 1990's after a series of visa programs aimed at countries "adversely 
affected" by the stricter immigration controls enacted in 1965. As these new immigrants use familial ties to sponsor 
people, legal immigration should continue to rise, experts predict. The latest immigration sweepstakes is the 
Diversity Immigrant Visa Lottery. It will make 55,000 permanent resident visas available annually to people from 
countries with low rates of immigration to the U.S. such as Japan and most of Western Europe. As a nation's rate 
rises or falls, it can be removed from or added to the list of eligible countries. New York City planners expect more 
people from eastern Europe and Africa as a result of the new program. The mail-in period for the first "DV-1" visas 
is June 1 to June 30.
